issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
This is similar, but different than other bugs (I think).
I've been running through test cases. Doing things that create a lot of resource (well, no more than 30-50 of any given thing). I have a lot of dialogs going up and down. CPU Is low. Threads are 33, Real Mem is 2.02 GB. This seems like a terminal issue since it will become unresponsive at some point. I already had to kill it once during the tests this morning.
I think this is different than some other bugs because there are no large data sets. It sounds a lot like something a customer had seen in 3.3.0
fields.summary: Firefox gobbles memory when doing normal console tasks

comments.body: I have seen it too. This condition is is aggravated by running the Selenium IDE suite.  I see symptoms after running it 2 times.
EUCA-7802 is very similar, probably the same root cause for browser becoming unresponsive.

This is a recording of memory usage by firefox while creating 50 volumes, then attempting to delete them. Notice some memory creep while creating the volumes (to 446MB), which gets a lot worse when deleting (approaching 3GB).

[~jpommer] and [~dkavanagh], once we have an idea of the fix for this, we can talk about whether or not we want to add this for 3.4.0 instead of waiting til 3.4.1. We need to get an idea of scope and risk for fix ASAP, please.

CC: [~tjcramer]/[~viglesias]

What I can tell at this point is when watching a volume model during delete, the model builds up a lot of "all" event listeners. I sampled several and it looks like the callback is _onModelEvent() in backbone. This is something backbone uses internally and is set up in the "set" method. There is a _removeReference() method that un-does this. Working on figuring out why things are going south here.

These are event listeners for one of the 17 volumes in the collection. That "all" set was only 3 or 4, till I deleted 10 volumes. Then, that and only that grew out of control (looks like it added 4 for each volume deleted).

[~kgill]

This is not blocking testing. If the change required is large/regression prone, then lets punt to 3.4.1 and call it a KI.

Observations from this morning's work;
- leaks on FF for mac seems almost twice as bad as FF on Windows
- ensuring databox re-used the same collection for it's output slices stopped runaway listener adding on the models
- extra "off" calls in rivets.js (our extensions to the library) helped a little more
- delete leaks way more memory than add (testing w/ volumes, but should apply to most resources)
- doing delete outside of the doMultiAction (and notification) structure takes memory leakage down a lot (but not completely)

Eliminated some huge listener creep in eucamodel... the code removed doesn't appear to even be necessary anymore.

Lesser listener creep identified in databox, and a workaround applied.

Found more listener creep in views/searches/generic.js:335 - Backbone.Collection constructor seems to add a listener each time it is called. We don't yet know why. Ean has some thoughts on how to get around the use of clone() in the searches and re-use collections to help with this.

After circumventing doMultiAction in the delete_volume dialog, Firefox memory consumption stays within more reasonable bounds when deleting 25 volumes at a time. Where David observed 2GB memory usage during that operation before, I now see about 450MB. But as stated by DK, this seems to be a much bigger problem on Mac (his test machine) than Win7 (my test machine).

Yet unresolved is my most recent observation of Firefox memory usage when creating 25 volumes, one at a time by hand. Memory footprint increased from around 350MB to just over 1GB, and did not recover. I'd like to test this again from the debug console tools and see if keeping the growler and dialogs out of it keeps Firefox from running away.
You should see much less memory being used (maybe 1/2) as compared to doing the same operations in 3.4
It is an improvement, but FF memory usage still unacceptable IMO. After running the Selenium IDE suite FF memory use is more than 1.3 GB
